defect.Description: Checkpoint: 3.3.1 Error Identification: Error messages are not associated with form fields, making it difficult for users to identify and correct input errors.
Checkpoint: 3.2.2 On Input: Form fields do not provide proper feedback to users when they make input errors, leading to confusion.
Checkpoint: 2.4.7 Focus Visible: Focus indicators are missing or not clearly visible, affecting keyboard users' ability to navigate the interface.
Checkpoint: 4.1.4 Resize text (Prerecorded) Defect: Users cannot resize text in prerecorded audio and video content, impacting accessibility.
Checkpoint: 1.4.6 Contrast (Enhanced) Defect: Enhanced color contrast is needed to meet accessibility standards, particularly for users with low vision.
Checkpoint: 2.2.3 No Timing Defect: Content relies on time-based interactions, excluding users who require extended time for tasks.
Checkpoint: 4.1.6 Audio Description (Prerecorded) Defect: Prerecorded audio content lacks audio descriptions, excluding users with vision impairments.
Checkpoint: 3.1.1 Language of Page Defect: The language of the web page is not programmatically identified, affecting screen reader pronunciation and translation.
Checkpoint: 2.4.2 Page Titled: The title displayed on two pages is incorrect
Checkpoint: 2.4.3 Focus Order:: The focus order of interactive elements does not follow a logical sequence, causing navigation difficulties for keyboard users.
Checkpoint: 1.4.4 Resize Text: Users are unable to resize text without loss of content or functionality, impacting accessibility for those with visual impairments.
Checkpoint: 2.4.6 Headings and Labels: Headings and labels are missing in several forms, making it challenging for users to understand the form's pu
Checkpoint: 4.1.5 Images of Text (Prerecorded) Defect: Images of text are used in prerecorded audio and video content, excluding screen reader users.
Checkpoint: 1.4.7 Low or No Background Audio (Prerecorded) Defect: Prerecorded audio content has distracting background sounds, affecting the comprehension of audio content.
Checkpoint: 2.2.4 Interruptions Defect: Auto-playing content interrupts users' tasks without warning, impacting user experience.
Checkpoint: 2.5.2 Pointer Cancellation Defect: The web application lacks a mechanism to cancel or undo pointer actions, causing usability issues.
Checkpoint: 3.2.4 Consistent Identification Defect: Interactive elements are not consistently identified across pages, causing confusion.
Checkpoint: 1.4.8 Visual Presentation Defect: Content relies on a specific visual presentation, excluding users who require alternative formats.
Checkpoint: 3.1.2 Language of Parts: The language of specific page elements is not programmatically identified, hindering screen reader pronunciation.
Checkpoint: 2.4.2 Page Titled: Some pages lack descriptive and meaningful titles, causing confusion during navigation.
Checkpoint: 2.2.1 Timing Adjustable: Users cannot control or disable automatically refreshing content, affecting those who need more time to read
Checkpoint: 1.2.5 Audio Description (Prerecorded): Videos lack audio descriptions, preventing users with vision impairments from understanding visual content.
Checkpoint: 1.4.1 Use of Color: Critical information is conveyed through color alone, excluding users with color blindness.
Checkpoint: 4.1.3 Status Messages Unannounced page changes are causing confusion for scree
Checkpoint: 4.1.3 Status Messages Unannounced page changes are causing confusion for screen reader users.
Key interactive elements are missing ARIA roles, causing screen readers to interpret them incorrectly.
Checkpoint: 3.1.1 Language of Page Defect: The language of the web page is not programmatically identified, affecting screen reader pronunciation and translation.
Checkpoint: 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions Defect: Form fields lack associated labels or instructions, making it challenging for users to provide correct input.
Some links in the documentation are not descriptive, making it unclear where they lead.
There is no "skip to content" link at the beginning of the page, causing keyboard and screen reader users to navigate through repetitive elements.
Checkpoint: 2.2.5 Re-authenticating Defect: Re-authentication mechanisms do not preserve user input, causing data loss.
Checkpoint: 2.5.3 Label in Name Defect: Some interactive elements do not include their label text within their accessible name, affecting screen reader users
Checkpoint: 3.2.5 Change on Request Defect: Changes to content or settings occur without user request, disrupting user tasks.
2.4.1 Bypass Blocks There is no "skip to content" link at the beginning of the page, causing keyboard and screen reader users to navigate through repetitive elements.
Checkpoint: 4.1.7 Audio Description (Extended) Defect: Prerecorded audio content lacks extended audio descriptions, excluding users with vision impairments.
Checkpoint: 2.1.1 Keyboard Users cannot navigate through the web application using only the keyboard; certain interactive elements are not accessible via keyboard input.
Checkpoint: 1.4.9 Images of Text (No Exception) Defect: Images of text are used without an accessible alternative, making it impossible for screen readers to interpret.
Checkpoint: 1.3.1 Info and Relationships Data tables do not have appropriate headers, making it difficult for screen reader users to understand the data's context.
1.2.2 Captions (Prerecorded) Videos in the knowledge base do not have captions, preventing users with hearing impairments from accessing the content.
Checkpoint 1.1.1 Non-text Content: Images on the homepage are missing alt text, making them inaccessible to screen readers.
Checkpoint: 2.2.1 Timing Adjustable: Users cannot control or disable automatically refreshing content, affecting those who need more time to read
Checkpoint: 3.2.1 On Focus Defect: Focus styles are missing for interactive elements, affecting keyboard navigation.
Checkpoint: 3.3.3 Error Suggestion Defect: Input error messages lack suggestions for correction, causing user frustration.
Checkpoint: 3.3.4 Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data) Defect: The web application lacks mechanisms to prevent or warn users of legal, financial, or data-related errors.
Checkpoint: 3.3.6 Error Prevention (All) Defect: The web application does not provide sufficient error prevention mechanisms, leading to user frustration.
Checkpoint: 2.4.5 Multiple Ways Defect: Some content can only be accessed through mouse actions, excluding keyboard-only users.
Checkpoint: 4.1.2 Name, Role, Value: Form fields and interactive elements do not have programmatically determined names or roles, affecting assistive technology.
Checkpoint: 3.2.3 Consistent Navigation: Navigation menus and buttons do not maintain a consistent structure across pages, leading to user disorientation.
Checkpoint: 2.5.1 Pointer Gestures Defect: Certain interactions require precise pointer gestures, making it inaccessible for users with motor disabilities.
Checkpoint: 3.3.5 Help Defect: Context-sensitive help or tooltips are missing, making it challenging for users to understand complex interactions.
